Award.AwardTitle: Rigidity in von Neumann Algebras; Connections and Applications to Orbit Equivalence and Geometric Group Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Within the general context of Popa's deformation/rigidity theory and building on principal investigator's prior research results, the goal of this project is to find new rigidity results for von Neumann algebras associated with group actions on probability spaces. The project revolves around the following main problems: (1) find new examples of actions of more "exotic" groups on probability spaces that can be completely reconstructed from their von Neumann algebras; (2) find additional examples of group actions that lead to von Neumann algebras with unique Cartan subalgebras; (3) obtain new applications to ergodic theory (particularly orbit equivalence and structural properties for equivalence relations) and probability theory (percolation on graphs); and (4) deepen the connections with geometric group theory and representation theory. The principal investigator plans to achieve these goals by further refining his previous techniques and continuing to expand the cohomological and geometric group theory perspective that he and his coauthors have brought to the study of rigidity in von Neumann algebras. He expects these techniques to reveal new aspects of the theory that will enable an even more fruitful interplay between these fields.

The study of von Neumann algebras was initiated in the 1930s by Murray and von Neumann as a tool to study quantum mechanics, and it has progressively morphed into a stand-alone discipline. It also created a basis for the development of powerful mathematical theories that ultimately brought valuable insight to areas of physics (statistical mechanics), biology (DNA structure), and engineering (cell-phone design). This project, which continues the study of rigidity phenomena in von Neumann algebras, is expected to generate novel applications and to establish new bridges to other active research areas in mathematics (probability, ergodic theory, and geometric aspects in group theory). On a broader scale, the principal investigator anticipates that applications of rigidity phenomena outside the mathematical spectrum will continue to unveil themselves, particularly in engineering and computer science (e.g., error-correcting codes). The project will offer numerous development opportunities for graduate students or young researchers just entering this very active research field. While the topic of the project is focused heavily on advanced trends, it also contains substantial research directions and open problems that can be excellent subjects for Ph.D. theses. The principal investigator is currently teaching a two-semester introductory course on this subject with the purpose of attracting new young talent to the area. He will continue to disseminate his findings from the project through publications, lecture series, and seminar and colloquium talks, and to promote the connections with related areas of mathematics and beyond.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Seeking a rigorous mathematical formalism for quantum mechanics, John von Neumann introduced in mid-thirties a class of new mathematical objects now known as von Neuman algebras. What was initially just an instrument to understand particle physics eventually morphed into a stand-alone discipline with deep connections with other areas of Mathematics, significantly group theory and ergodic theory. This is best illustrated by an early fundamental result asserting that groups and their actions on spaces naturally give rise to a class of von Neumann algebras termed factors. Ever since their introduction, classifying factors in term of their group/actions initial data has emerged as a major direction of research in this area and generated overtime a spectacular progress and development of new exciting theories.

The introduction of Popa's deformation/rigidity theory, fifteen years ago, completely revolutionized the study of von Neumann algebras by providing solutions to many long-standing open problems and also initiating new avenues of research. This novel approach provided the necessary technical framework for the study of the so-called rigidity phenomena in the context of von Neumann algebras. Rigidity in mathematics is the condition that allows one to recognize the entire structure of an object, just from limited a priori information.  

Through this project, the PI and his collaborators found new inputs in deformation/rigidity theory by developing various new tools that implement algebraic, geometric, and cohomological group information into the analytic setting of factors. This fresh perspective enabled the PI to unveil large classes of examples of groups and actions that are completely reconstructible from their factors - one of the main goals of the proposed project. In addition, these techniques allowed the PI to identify new algebraic features of a group that are entirely remembered by its factor. These results establish new rigidity phenomena in the literature and have deep consequences to the current understanding of the structure of factors. More importantly, these results/methods have stirred significant subsequent developments from other researchers in the field. In a different direction, the PI found new methods to distinguish non-separable factors thus leading to the solution of a well-known open problem in the model theory of factors.

The themes of study presented in this project carry significant relevance to other areas of Mathematics and beyond, such as: C*-algebras, geometric and representation aspects in group theory, ergodic theory, free probability, logic, computer science, and quantum information theory.  Some of the techniques developed by the PI and his collaborators unveiled new links between deformation/rigidity theory and these areas, ultimately leading to a rich cross-pollination of ideas between these fields. This interdisciplinary activity generated an array of interesting open questions in group theory, ergodic theory, and logic thus triggering new studies from various visible scientists within these disciplines.

During the award period the PI has broadly disseminated his research findings through publications, colloquia, seminars, and other invited talks at various high-profile national and international events. To promote the visibility of von Neumann algebras he organized several conferences and year-long seminars both at University of Iowa and other institutions. At his home institution, he designed and taught new courses in von Neumann algebras and related fields that eventually attracted four new graduate students to this area of research. Two of these students have earned their doctoral degrees in the summer of 2017, their dissertations making significant progress on several of the open problems from this project. These achievements earned one of them (also a minority student) a prestigious 3-years RTG position at UCLA. The third student is also very advanced and expected to graduate in two years or less. While training the Iowa team for the Putnam competition, the PI has recruited a senior undergraduate student. Currently he is supervising this student undergraduate research on an open problem that arose from this project.
